article.name: What's the Difference Between Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains?
article.title: What's the Difference Between Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains?
article.body:
Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains

Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains are both used in phishing campaigns, but they serve different purposes. See the table below for more information.

Phish Link Domains

Landing Domains

A phish link domain is a URL used for the simulated phishing link within a test email. Users can see this URL when they hover their mouse over the link, button, or image.

When creating a phishing campaign, you can set the phish link domain to random or select a specific domain. 

You also have the option to create custom phish link domains and hide unwanted domains. 

For more information, see our Phishing Domain Management article.

When a user clicks on a simulated phishing link, the phish link domain will redirect them to a landing domain. Users can see this URL in the address bar of their browser when they view a landing page. 

In your Account Settings, you can set a default landing domain to be used across all email templates. 

When creating a custom email template, you have the option to select a domain that is different from your default landing domain. 

For more information, see our Account Settings article and our How to Create and Edit Email Templates and Landing Pages article. 
Note: All Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains are owned by KnowBe4 and are only used for the purposes of simulated phishing tests.

images.alt:
The image displays a sectional view of a digital interface, illustrating the behavior of a hyperlink upon mouse hover.

**UI Elements and Interaction:**

1.  **Hyperlink (Anchor Text):** A full URL, formatted as a blue hyperlink, is visible: `https://www.webmail-report.com/bug-reports`.
2.  **Cursor:** A hand-pointer cursor icon indicates an active hover state over the link.
3.  **Tooltip/URL Preview:** A solid, dark gray rectangular tooltip is generated below the hyperlink, standard behavior for displaying the actual destination URL.
4.  **Tooltip Content:** The text within the gray preview box, displayed in white font, is the destination domain: `oldmacdonald.had-a.phish.farm`.

**Contextual Text:**

The hyperlink is positioned above the standard black body text fragment: `Thank you,`. The image demonstrates a discrepancy between the visible anchor text and the actual destination URL (as shown in the hover preview).
images.context: shing campaign, you can set the phish link domain to random or select a specific domain.

images.alt:
The image displays the title bar and address bar of a web browser interface.

**UI Elements and Text:**

1.  **Window Controls:** Standard red, yellow, and green circular controls (close, minimize, maximize) are visible on the far left.
2.  **Active Tab:** The current tab is titled **"Oops!"** and features a dark, abstract icon (resembling an intertwined 'S' or stylized globe) set within an orange circular border. A close button ('x') is present on the tab edge.
3.  **Navigation Bar:** Includes standard browser controls: a disabled/faded back arrow, an enabled/dark forward arrow, and a refresh/reload circular arrow icon.
4.  **Address Bar (Omnibox):** Preceded by the same dark, abstract site icon, the full URL displayed is: **`https://oops.yourgunnalovetraining.com`**.
